The big kernel lock (BKL) was a single global lock that serialized all accesses to the kernel data structures in early versions of the Linux kernel. Over time, the Linux kernel has adopted a variety of fine-grained locking mechanisms that allow multiple parts of the kernel to run concurrently and improve system performance. Some examples of these locking mechanisms include:

* Spinlocks: These locks allow concurrent access to shared data structures in a kernel-space context.
* Read-Write locks: These locks allow multiple readers to access a shared resource simultaneously, but only one writer can modify the resource at a time.
* Semaphores: These locks are used to coordinate access to shared resources between multiple processes.
* Mutexes: These locks are used to serialize access to shared resources in a multithreaded environment.
* RCU (Read-Copy-Update): This mechanism allows the kernel to update data structures without disabling interrupts or acquiring locks.

These locking mechanisms have replaced the BKL in the Linux kernel and improved system performance by reducing contention and allowing multiple parts of the kernel to run concurrently.
